$150 IN PRIZES ARE TO BE
AWARDED IN SEASON
TICKET SALE
Fraternity and Individual Selling the
Greatest Number to Divide
Large Award

Repeating last year's method of
selling Spring Season Tickets, the
Athletic ASsociation hopes to absolve .the $7,200 deficit they placed
at the beginning of football season. A total in prizes of $150 will
be awarded to the fraternity and individual selling the largest number
of tickets. The campaign will cover
the, period from March 9 to March
30, when it will close-at six o'clock.
To Elect Captains

Fraternities will elect team captains who will obtain tickets for the
groups at the Athletic office, and distribute them among the Members of
his chapter. Each fraternity will
visit Hopkins alumni, not necessarily its own fraternity alumni, and
offer them season'tickets' for track
and lacrosse for five dollars.
Last year fall sports made money
in spite of the weak support of the
campus in the ticket campaign, but
not enough to overcome a large
debt. A rainy season in lacrosse
would practically spell disaster for
the Association, according to Graduate Manager Keyes.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 25, 1927

LACROSSE PRACTICE .
SOON,SAYS:KEYES
"Depending on the weather,
lacrosse practice will start
about March 1," Norman C.
Keyes, Graduate Manager of
Athletics, announced last week.
Mr. Keyes hopes and expects
to see a large number of candidates come out for the team.
There are 'fifteen or sixteen
men of the squad left over
from last season, but these are
nearly all 'defense men. Mallonee, Leibensperger, Biddison, Kegan and Finn are
among those back from last
year. "The team is badly in
need of attack men," states
Mr. Keyes.

PLANS FOR VARSITY CLUB
SMOKER PROGRESSING
RAPIDLY
Committees and Representatives
Invite Prominent Prep
School Men

Plans are well under way for the
Prep School Smoker to be given by
the Varsity Club on Saturday evening, March 12th, at the C. E. Hall.
The Executive Board, which consists of the alumni officers of the
Club, met yesterday at luncheon at
the Merchants Club. The plans in
full detail were presented by Chairman J. Albert Abraham and endorsed by the Board.
The purpose of this smoker is to
afford an opportunity for prep
school men to become acquainted
with the calibre of men on our campus. Though sponsored by the, Varsity Club, this event will not be a
purely athletic issue. Prep-school
men, prominent in non-athletic activities as well as athletics, will be
Present. And in addition to the
Varsity Club, there will be representatives of our own non-athletic activities invited. In other words, the
smoker will be in the nature of a
"mixer."

TRACK EQUIPMENT TO
BE DISTRIBUTED
Track men will be given
equipment today and the lockers will also be assigned. The
equipment will be distributed
at four o'clock at Homewood
Field.
Practice is to begin next
Monday, February 28, and will
be held daily at four o'clock
during the week and at threethirty on Saturdays.
"Only one man has announced himself as a candidate
for the junior managership
left vacant by Joseph Watkins," said Manager Niles.
More junior and freshman
candidates are needed, according to the track manager.

DR. GOODNOW TELLS
OF FUTURE POLICY
Separation of First Two Years
from Last Imminent
YALE JURIST IS SPEAKER
Portraits Presented;. Degrees .Are
Awarded at Peabody
Abandonment of the first two
years of college work at the University will not go into effect for an
indefinite time, according to a statement made by President Frank J.
Goodnow at the Fifty-first Commemoration Day Exercises held at
the Peabody Institute, Tuesday
morning.
"The reasons why no .statement
may now be made are two," continued Dr. Goodnow. "They are first
that we have a local duty to perform. We cannot take any action
which is going to leave a gap between the reorganized University
and the local schools which cannot
be filled. At present one of the city
high schools takes care of one of the
two years which we should like to
drop and in three years the other
city high school will be in the same
position. I furthermore feel certain
that if the boys of Baltimore wishing in the future to enter the reorganized university in order to do
advanced work would remain another year at one or the other of the
city high schools, as under present
arrangements they may, they would
be able to satisfy the requirements
of most of our University departments. So far as concerns the
young men from the counties of the
state, they are now provided for in
other Maryland colleges or could if
they so desired take the work at the
city high schools which they were
unable to get in the county high
schools."

TEMPLE GOTHIC
Dr. Ernst Diez Describes Borobudur
Temple Built by Buddhists

"The art of the Borobudur, the
temple of a thousand Buddhas, has
much in common with that of the
Gothic structures of the Christian
religion built during the middle
ages," asserted Dr. Ernst Diez, of
Bryn Mawr College, in his lecture
last Friday afternoon at the Civil
Engineering Building on "The Art
of the Borobudur." This great temple displays simple strength, the
simple fervor of the Buddhist religion at the time of its construction.
On Island of Java

The Borobudur temple was built
about the same time in the development of the Buddhist religion, as
the Gothic churches in that of the
Christian religion. It is in the island
of Java, where Buddhism came to
have great strength. It was completed in the sixth century, and was
used for two centuries. Then, however, with the spread of Mohammedanism, it was deserted. Off and
on for a century or two it was in
use, then entirely neglected.
Discovered by English

In the early part of the nineteenth
century it was discovered by the
English, but nothing was done for
its restoration. In 1907, however,
the Dutch government appropriated
Iiioney for its restoration, and architects were sent out to study the
building, which was practically in
ruins.
"This old temple," Dr. Diez
pointed out, "is one of the great
monuments of the world." It is
built in the old original style of architecture: terrace on terrace. It

$150 IN PRIZES ARE TO BE
AWARDED IN SEASON
TICKET SALE
Fraternity and Individual Selling the
Greatest Number to Divide
Large Award

Repeating last year's method of
selling Spring Season Tickets, the
Athletic ASsociation hopes to absolve .the $7,200 deficit they placed
at the beginning of football season. A total in prizes of $150 will
be awarded to the fraternity and individual selling the largest number
of tickets. The campaign will cover
the, period from March 9 to March
30, when it will close-at six o'clock.
To Elect Captains

Fraternities will elect team captains who will obtain tickets for the
groups at the Athletic office, and distribute them among the Members of
his chapter. Each fraternity will
visit Hopkins alumni, not necessarily its own fraternity alumni, and
offer them season'tickets' for track
and lacrosse for five dollars.
Last year fall sports made money
in spite of the weak support of the
campus in the ticket campaign, but
not enough to overcome a large
debt. A rainy season in lacrosse
would practically spell disaster for
the Association, according to Graduate Manager Keyes.

year. "The team is badly in
need of attack men," states

PLANS FOR VARSITY CLUB
SMOKER PROGRESSING
RAPIDLY
Committees and Representatives
Invite Prominent Prep
School Men

Plans are well under way for the
Prep School Smoker to be given by
the Varsity Club on Saturday evening, March 12th, at the C. E. Hall.
The Executive Board, which consists of the alumni officers of the
Club, met yesterday at luncheon at
the Merchants Club. The plans in
full detail were presented by Chairman J. Albert Abraham and endorsed by the Board.
The purpose of this smoker is to
afford an opportunity for prep
school men to become acquainted
with the calibre of men on our campus. Though sponsored by the, Varsity Club, this event will not be a
purely athletic issue. Prep-school
men, prominent in non-athletic activities as well as athletics, will be
Present. And in addition to the
Varsity Club, there will be representatives of our own non-athletic activities invited. In other words, the
smoker will be in the nature of a
"mixer."

TRACK EQUIPMENT TO
BE DISTRIBUTED
Track men will be given
equipment today and the lockers will also be assigned. The
equipment will be distributed
at four o'clock at Homewood
Field.
Practice is to begin next
Monday, February 28, and will
be held daily at four o'clock
during the week and at threethirty on Saturdays.
"Only one man has announced himself as a candidate
for the junior managership
left vacant by Joseph Watkins," said Manager Niles.
More junior and freshman
candidates are needed, according to the track manager.

OF FUTURE POLICY
Separation of First Two Years
from Last Imminent
YALE JURIST IS SPEAKER
Portraits Presented;. Degrees .Are
Awarded at Peabody
Abandonment of the first two
years of college work at the University will not go into effect for an
indefinite time, according to a statement made by President Frank J.
Goodnow at the Fifty-first Commemoration Day Exercises held at
the Peabody Institute, Tuesday
morning.
"The reasons why no .statement
may now be made are two," continued Dr. Goodnow. "They are first
that we have a local duty to perform. We cannot take any action
which is going to leave a gap between the reorganized University
and the local schools which cannot
be filled. At present one of the city
high schools takes care of one of the
two years which we should like to
drop and in three years the other
city high school will be in the same
position. I furthermore feel certain
that if the boys of Baltimore wishing in the future to enter the reorganized university in order to do
advanced work would remain another year at one or the other of the
city high schools, as under present
arrangements they may, they would
be able to satisfy the requirements
of most of our University departments. So far as concerns the
young men from the counties of the
state, they are now provided for in
other Maryland colleges or could if
they so desired take the work at the
city high schools which they were
unable to get in the county high
schools."

Mr. Leys, Harvard Graduate, Will

H. Garland Hershey, W. B.
Hammond, and W. R. McDorman
will comprise the sophomore team
which is to debate the freshmen at
the assembly next Thursday, March
3. By common consent, the freshmen have selected the affirmative
and the sophomores the negative of
the question: "Resolved, that freshman regulations in the American
College be abandoned."
Hershey is chairman of the sophomore team and will probably take
the rebuttal against Spear. J. Valliant has been chosen sophomore alternate.

o'clock, in the Homewood Playshop.
The lecture will be under the auspices of the Woman's Club, and will
be open to all students of the university.

ARCHITECTURE OF JAVAN
TEMPLE GOTHIC
Dr. Ernst Diez Describes Borobudur
Temple Built by Buddhists

"The art of the Borobudur, the
temple of a thousand Buddhas, has
much in common with that of the
Gothic structures of the Christian
religion built during the middle
ages," asserted Dr. Ernst Diez, of
Bryn Mawr College, in his lecture
last Friday afternoon at the Civil
Engineering Building on "The Art
of the Borobudur." This great temple displays simple strength, the
simple fervor of the Buddhist religion at the time of its construction.
On Island of Java

The Borobudur temple was built
about the same time in the development of the Buddhist religion, as
the Gothic churches in that of the
Christian religion. It is in the island
of Java, where Buddhism came to
have great strength. It was completed in the sixth century, and was
used for two centuries. Then, however, with the spread of Mohammedanism, it was deserted. Off and
on for a century or two it was in
use, then entirely neglected.
Discovered by English

In the early part of the nineteenth
century it was discovered by the
English, but nothing was done for
its restoration. In 1907, however,
the Dutch government appropriated
Iiioney for its restoration, and architects were sent out to study the
building, which was practically in
ruins.
"This old temple," Dr. Diez
pointed out, "is one of the great
monuments of the world." It is
built in the old original style of architecture: terrace on terrace. It
